text:
- [Announcer] Farming's role
in global greenhouse gases
is undeniable,
accounting for 25% of all emissions.
Enter Monarch Tractor,

a big loop revolution
growing in the fields.

Monarch's Wingspan AI is
a cloud-based hub on AWS
that provides farmers with insights
gained from the infield operations.

The Monarch OS, nestled
in the tractor's roof,
provides driving-safe autonomous mobility
with a strategic blueprint.
Join "All Things Automotive" as we see

how Monarch Tractor is
rewriting the farming narrative.
(energetic music)
- Hello, everybody, Stefano here.
Today, I'm super happy,

because we're gonna introduce
a new type of vehicles
in "All Things Automotive."

We talked about cars,
we talked about trucks,

and today, we are gonna
talk about tractors,

and specifically, electric
autonomous tractors,
with our guest from Monarch.
Hello, Chris, how you doing?
- Hi there, good to be here.

- So can you tell us a
little bit about Monarch
and your role in there?
- Yeah, sure; my role in Monarch,
I'm the Chief Digital Officer,

so I look after anything
to do with autonomy, data,
software-related stuff,

and, you know, as we talk
about our architecture,
anything from the physical tractor,
everything up to the cloud,
I look at everything above the roof,
so the smart side of what we do,
anything to do with digitization.
- So Chris, it seems to me
that you really have a great recipe
for innovation for the agriculture sector,
big data, connectivity IOT,
and then artificial intelligence.
It's what we call the big loop
with the regular passenger car vehicles.

You are building the big loop
for the agriculture sector.
So Chris, why can't we have a look

at what's behind it in
terms of architecture?
- Yeah, the architecture,
I guess, from a logical standpoint,
we're really gonna focus on three layers.
At the bottom, we have the tractor,
which is essentially an IOT device.
In technical terms, it's an endpoint

which we're gonna
connect to our top layer,
which is the cloud.
That's what we call Wingspan AI,

it's where all of our
smarts in the cloud run.
And in the middle, we have a layer
which we call the edge,

the technology we use is
called a base station,

and it's a way that we can
connect the two things together

to do with things like
synchronization, data transfer,
managing our communications, et cetera.

So at the bottom, we've got
the roof on the tractor.
What our roof essentially is,
we've taken a standard roof,

which is basically there
to protect the driver,

rocks, roll-over protection,
falling object protection,

and we've put all of our
compute, and sensors,
and communication devices in there,
and essentially built a computer,

so we call it the smart
roof, it's a computer,
and we have a layer of software in there
called the Monarch Operating System,
which is essentially the smarts.
That's the thing that allows us
to automate the operations of the tractor,
to make it self-driving,
to basically collect data,
collect sensor data, do analytics,
do perception, do object detection,
all of that stuff is done in the tractor.
- Yeah, that's absolutely cool.

And I assume that you
start to use AWS service

in the transport, right, of
this heterogenous kind of data
to the cloud, correct?
- That's correct, that's correct.

So from the tractor, through
the edge, to the cloud,
we use services like Amazon's IOT service.
Like I say, our tractor is an IOT endpoint
that we connect to the cloud,

and so we have many,
many of these endpoints
coming into the cloud,
so we use the IOT service.
That provides us

with a very, very secure
data transport mechanism

through our edge, to the
tractor, to the cloud,
so that's kinda like our bottom layer,

how do we get data in and
also out of the cloud.
So when we're doing OTA,
over-the-air updates of our tractors,
we need to bring data down.
- And then I assume I see

some different kind of
storages here, so databases,
so can you tell us a little bit?
- Absolutely, I mean,

we use multiple storage
technologies from AWS.

Like I say, we collect many,
many different types of data.
We collect very, very unstructured data,
so a lot of our video feeds,

I mean, there's various
formats of information in there
that we need to analyze later on.
We have semi-structured data,

a lot of log files around
what's happening on the tractor.

And then a lot of
transactional record data,
the operation, who's doing what,

where are they doing it,
why are they doing it.

All of that data comes
through the IOT layer,

and so we have to use
different storage technologies
to do that,
and so also foundational for us is S3.
Everything initially goes into S3.
We use RDS

for doing more of our kinda
like SQL relationship data.

We use Redis for more kind
of like graph-oriented data.

And then everything
eventually ends up in Glacier
for long-term storage.

- Yeah, in some of those
aspect in automation,
the data movement,
as well as, probably, Lambda or serverless
played a role, I'd assume.
- Yeah, absolutely.
And the Lambda functions
is one of the primary things that we do,
because, you know,

we have to basically break
up kind of our intelligence
into different types of bits.

We have many, many functions
looking at this data,

so we don't have big monolithic
algorithms that are running,
we need to break those things up.
- I see two layers of APIs there,

one, probably, for applications
or web applications,

and the other for
ecosystem, as you call it,
so can you talk about that a little?
- Yeah, most of our ecosystem stuff,
we use a lot of rest APIs,

so for bringing data in
from our third parties,
getting data out to our third parties,
so we're very particular about our APIs,
'cause we need to publish those APIs,

and we need to make sure
we keep them constant.
And then for the farmers,

which is ultimately the
end user of Wingspan AI,

they come in through mobile
devices, web devices,
those type of things,
smart watches, eventually, hopefully,

and so we have a lot of,
lot of different queries
that we need to do that,

because we visualize
data in different ways.

Sometimes it's geospatial,
sometimes it's temporal,

sometimes we have live
video feeds going out,
sometimes it's just general data queries,
so we have two types of APIs,

stuff that goes out to
our third-party ecosystem,

information that's
transferred from our farmers
via their graphical user interfaces.

- Yeah, and they're probably
why we see CDN there, right,

so CloudFront,
- Absolutely, yeah.
- because probably, you need to speed up

- sending (indistinct)
- Yeah, absolutely.
CloudFront is very, very important for us

for the wide-scale kinda like
distribution of those queries,

and, you know, because our
farmers can be anywhere,
I mean, theoretically,
anywhere around the world, as we scale,

you know, CloudFront is a
very, very important part

of our architecture.
- Yeah.
And last but not least,
I see that you're using SNS
for the notification, probably.
I assume there's plenty.
I dunno, it's coming,

it's about to start rain,
- Yeah.

- so you gotta go there, and-
- Absolutely.

Yeah, I mean, awareness
anytime, any place, anywhere

is kinda like one of
our foundational mottos
for Wingspan AI,

'cause what we're really
trying to do with Wingspan AI
is keep the farmer informed,
we wanna give them actionable insights,
so it doesn't really matter

whether they're on a
mobile device, using SMS,
or whether they're on email,
we need to get hold of people,

so SES is kinda like one
of the foundational things,
'cause everybody reads emails.

- Thank you so much, Chris,
for such a rich episode.
- No problem, my pleasure, thank you.
(energetic music)

- [Announcer] The future
looks green for Monarch.

Global expansion beyond
California is on the horizon,
fueled by the partnership with AWS.

With a shift to microservices,
the journey continues,

integrating fresh data and
apps via third party APIs.
Already branching into diverse domains
like new crops and dairy,

Monarch is planting seeds
of innovation far and wide

as they work to reshape
the future of agriculture.
(energetic music)
